awd_titl_txt: Columbus State Community College STEM Scholarship Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Columbus State Community College in Ohio, in collaboration with high school and university partners, will address the national, regional, and local need for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workers. The project will create a scholarship program that is designed to recruit economically disadvantaged students with high academic potential into Associate of Science transfer STEM programs and provide financial support and student support services to ensure student success and completion. The educational supports will result in well-qualified STEM graduates who can transfer to a university, earn a baccalaureate degree, and fill industry needs.  The project will deliver a high quality curriculum and an extensive evaluation of project activities. It has an aggressive plan to ensure full participation for underrepresented women and minority students. The project will create new research data on which activities have the greatest impacts on student success. With such information, future STEM projects will build on this discovery to improve services. An extensive evaluation plan will yield unbiased data on which components of the project are most successful. The lessons learned and project outcomes will be disseminated broadly to enable other colleges to craft projects to engage low-income aspiring STEM students. 

The project is led by STEM faculty members with years of experience who have developed a well-reasoned set of activities based on student success literature. The college has extensive resources to enable a successful project including a new STEM Resource Center, which will be a major focal point for student engagement. The overall project goals are to (a) increase the recruitment, retention, student success, transfer and graduation of low-income, academically talented students with demonstrated financial need pursuing an Associate of Science degree in STEM disciplines; (b) implement and study a STEM scholarship program, that includes STEM advising and enhanced curriculum, evaluating effective best practices to better understand the factors of supportive curricular and co-curricular activities that affect recruitment, retention, student success, academic/career pathways, and/or degree attainment (including student transfer); and (c) sustain effective curricular and co-curricular activities for low-income academically talented students with financial need, pursuing STEM education at the college. During the five-year project 48 students will participate as S-STEM scholars. The project will involve (a) activities for all S-STEM Scholars that include an annual scholarship, weeklong summer bridge program for incoming freshmen, STEM Club, dedicated STEM advisor, STEM Resource Center, career counseling, internship opportunities, cohort class scheduling, early alerts, and peer mentoring; and (b) optional activities available to S-STEM Scholars including intervention-based tutoring, supplemental instruction, student support services available through other college programs, a first-year STEM seminar series, and STEM-focused service learning opportunities.

por.por_cntn:
Project Summary

The Columbus State Community College’s (CSCC) S-STEM program in the Biological and Physical Sciences department for economically disadvantaged students focused on holistic, outside-of-the-classroom student support in addition to providing full-tuition scholarships. Student Support practices included a STEM Summer Bridge program for incoming freshman, cohort-based course scheduling, a dedicated STEM Resource room, career-focused seminar series, an 8-week research ethics course, faculty-student mentorship, and an embedded full-time STEM academic advisor. Project objectives focused on increased retention, course completion, and graduation/transfers in addition to post-completion STEM placement. Reflective evaluations sought to assess the feasibility, efficacy, and sustainability in continuing and replicating the program within the institution.

Key Accomplishments

  1. Program Recruitment and Completion – Over the project, 63 economically disadvantaged students in five cohorts were recruited focusing on including underrepresented minorities. From all cohorts, 74% of the participants graduated with an Associate of Science degree and 77% transferred to a four-year institution. Student self-evaluation reflected increased confidence in student goals for graduation and post-completion plans in addition to a a greater sense of belonging within the cohorts and at the institution.
  2. Student Success Practices – Strategies that highly influenced participant success as compared to those outside the S-STEM program included a designated STEM advisor and faculty mentor, STEM Club cohort activities and accessibility of resources, and the Summer Bridge Program. Capacity for advising case management increased to full-time which facilitated intentional connections for students and resulted in higher performance than the comparison group and sustained positional support beyond the project end. Similarly, innovations for faculty mentorship and the STEM club have created successful, replicable models in other parts of the college with focuses on sustainability and student-lead leadership. Finally, the Summer Bridge increased student belonging, connection, and college preparedness with several successful replications in other Columbus State college readiness programs.

Impact

At the program level, several practices will continue beyond the completion of the grant project including a full-time designated advisor, faculty mentorship, STEM Club, and the Summer Bridge Program. These sustained practices will increase student recruitment, engagement, and completion within the Biological and Physical Sciences department with the goal of job placement in the STEM field. Outside the program, the college continues to use the successes and lessons learned in other S-STEM and student success programming, specifically centering the strategies that influenced the high rates of belonging and support. The impact of this S-STEM program affirms the college’s commitment to creating a diverse and prepared workforce in the Central Ohio region while continuing to support student wellbeing and academic success.

 


Last Modified: 03/26/2024
Modified by: Adam I Keller
